intro: Paronychia mexicana subsp. mexicana, commonly known as the Mexican sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are usually pink or purple, which bloom in the spring and summer. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often covered with fine hairs, and it has a compact growth habit. It is well adapted to drought conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
